Organs/Tissues: Broad range: vascular endothelium, epithelial barriers, tumor–endothelial interaction, immune infiltration, etc.
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Normal shear conditions for vascular physiology or disease states (inflammation, thrombosis, metastasis)
Cell Source: Any adherent cell line or primary/iPSC-derived cells. Commonly endothelium, tumor cells, fibroblasts, immune cells
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (co-culture on channel walls or sequential seeding). Can flow immune cells over confluent endothelium
Stromal Cells: Yes, if used in layered approaches or a 3D matrix (less common in 2D channel, but possible as a thin gel layer)
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible if seeded with the main cell population (e.g. macrophages in a monolayer). Rare in pure 2D though
Circulating Immune: Yes, perfusion of leukocytes or other blood cells to observe rolling/adhesion/transmigration
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Limited in a single channel. Users may chain multiple slides in series or do multi-step experiments
Air-Liquid Interface: Not standard. Typically fully liquid-filled channels. ALI usage would require custom arrangement
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, surface coatings (collagen, fibronectin). 2D environment, typically not thick 3D ECM
3D Scaffold: Not in the standard 2D channel. Typically 2D monolayers. Some advanced usage might embed thin gels
Notable Features: Well-established slides for cell culture under flow. Optimal for real-time microscopy of 2D cell layers
Plate/Format (Throughput): Slide format (1–6 parallel channels). Low–medium throughput. Each channel = 1 condition
Max Culture Duration: Days to ~2 weeks under continuous flow, depending on cell viability
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, made for high-quality microscopy (phase, fluorescence, confocal)
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, from outlet. Minimal volume in channel. Easy to collect for assays
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible via trypsin flush. Usually used for in situ imaging/staining
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In situ. Slide not designed to be opened. Typically image-based endpoints
Readouts - TEER: No integrated electrodes. Could possibly measure if user modifies. Not typical
Readouts - MEA: No built-in. Usually not combined with electrophysiology in standard slides
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No. Just optical imaging. External or off-chip sensors for biochemical readouts
Dead Volume: Low (~30 µL in each channel). Minimizes reagent use, rapid solution exchange
Perfused: Yes, with Ibidi Pump or other pumps. Stable or pulsed flow for shear stress studies
Gas Mix Controlled: In an incubator or with Ibidi stage incubator. Slide is closed, so rely on medium pre-equilibration
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate easily changed mid-experiment. Media/drug switching possible. No built-in automation
model_availability: Commercial product. Purchase µ-Slides & optional Ibidi Pump. User seeds and designs the biology

Organs/Tissues: 3D cell models: tumor spheroids, organoids (heart, kidney, etc.), tissues in hydrogel
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Allows normal 3D tissue architecture or disease states (cancer, fibrotic, infected organoids)
Cell Source: Spheroids from cell lines or patient-derived, iPSC organoids, ex vivo tissue fragments in a 3D matrix
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (co-culture in 3D). E.g. tumor cells + fibroblasts + immune cells in a single spheroid
Stromal Cells: Yes, embedded with parenchymal cells in the gel or forming a 3D stromal environment
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, can incorporate macrophages or other immune subsets into the organoid or gel
Circulating Immune: Yes, if user connects a perfusion channel around the 3D construct and introduces immune cells
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Each slide typically houses one 3D tissue or spheroid set. Multi-organ crosstalk would require linking multiple slides
Air-Liquid Interface: No standard ALI. These slides are closed channels for 3D fluidic perfusion
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, fill the chamber with collagen, Matrigel, or fibrin to embed cells
3D Scaffold: Core feature. The user places spheroids or seeds cells in a 3D gel inside the perfusion chamber
Notable Features: Built for live imaging of 3D constructs under flow. Maintains nutrient gradients, fosters real 3D cell behavior
Plate/Format (Throughput): Slide-based. Typically 1–2 or a few 3D constructs per slide. Low–medium throughput. Parallel slides for multiple conditions
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks. Continuous flow feeding organoids or spheroids. Extended viability vs. static culture
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, high-quality optical transparency for confocal or widefield. Real-time observation of 3D structures
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, from outlet line. Good for secretome analysis
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possibly remove spheroids by pipette if not strongly embedded, or do in situ endpoint. Slide not easily opened
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In situ confocal is typical. For histology, can attempt to recover the gel. Not straightforward
Readouts - TEER: No integrated electrodes. Typically not for barrier measurement, but 3D tissue function
Readouts - MEA: No. Spheroid slides lack electrodes. Usually rely on optical readouts
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No built-in chemical sensors. Rely on external sampling or imaging dyes
Dead Volume: Low channel volume. Minimizes reagent usage, ensures quick media changes
Perfused: Yes, with Ibidi Pump or other systems. Provides nutrients & shear around 3D constructs
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator-based or stage-top incubator for CO₂. Medium can be pre-equilibrated. No direct O₂ control
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate, media composition can be changed mid-culture. Automated or manual pump control
model_availability: Commercial product from Ibidi. Users embed 3D culture (organoids/spheroids) in the slides
